optionalFeatureTypes.DZC:CS:WS: Fighter Rework; Combat Specialization: Weapon Specialization
optionalFeatureTypes.DZC:CS:AS: Fighter Rework; Combat Specialization: Armor Specialization
optionalFeatureTypes.DZC:CS:PS: Fighter Rework; Combat Specialization: Physical Specialization

tools: Choose one type of {@item artisan's tools|phb} or one kind of {@item vehicle|phb}

default: (a) a {@item chain mail|phb} or (b) {@item leather armor|phb}, {@item longbow}, {@item quiver}, and {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows}
(a) {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} and a {@item shield|phb} or (b) two {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon}
(a) a {@item light crossbow|phb}, a {@item crossbow bolt case|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) two {@item simple weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple wepaon}
(a) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}

classFeature.name: Warrior's Training
entries: At 1st level, you take upon a training regime in order to cultivate your fighting prowess, which takes on the form of a {@filter Combat Specialization|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:CS}, each one is described below.
You learn two features of your choice from any Combat Specialization. When you reach 9th and 13th level in this class, you learn an additional feature of your choice from any specialization.

entries.name: Weapon Specialization
entries: To overwhelm your opponent, to skillfully wield your weapons in different ways to use them in unique ways, that is the key to success in the battlefield.

entries.name: Armor Specialization
entries: Those foolish enough will say that the best defense is the best offense, however, the best defense is that which allows you to fight longer.

entries.name: Physical Specialization
entries: Your body takes the major part of the work load, making it the most important part to train.

entries.name: Changes to Unarmed Strikes and the Finesse Property
entries: In this compendium unarmed strikes and the finesse property suffer important changes meant to keep balance in check.

entries.name: Finesse Property
entries: The property now allows to choose between your Strength or Dexterity modifier only for the attack roll with the weapon, but not for the damage roll. For the damage roll you still have to use your Strength modifier for melee weapon attacks or your Dexterity modifier for ranged weapon attacks.

entries.name: Unarmed Strikes
entries: Unarmed strikes are now considered to have the finesse and light properties.

classFeature.name: Warrior's Training improvement
entries: At 9th level, you learn an additional {@filter Combat Specialization|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:CS} of your choice from any specialization.

classFeature.name: Warrior's Training improvement
entries: At 13th level, you learn an additional {@filter Combat Specialization|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:CS} of your choice from any specialization.

classFeature.name: Pump Action
entries: At 1st level, on your turn, you can forgo your bonus action and your reaction to take an additional action this turn.

classFeature.name: Combat Superiority
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you learn {@filter Maneuvers|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:M} that are fueled by special dice called superiority dice.

entries.name: Maneuvers
entries: You learn three {@filter maneuvers|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:M} of your choice. Your maneuvers are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain fighter levels, you gain additional maneuvers of your choice, as shown in the Maneuvers Known column of the Fighter table.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace a maneuver you know with another one.

entries.name: Superiority Dice
entries: You have a special die called Superiority Dice, as shown in the Superiority Dice column of the Fighter table. You have a pool of these die available, as shown in the Superiority Pool column of said table. Whenever you use a maneuver, you spend a Superiority Dice. You regain all of your expended die when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: Some of your maneuvers require your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Determination
entries: You can't fail, not when everyone depends on you. At 2nd level, you can cancel the disadvantage or a penalty to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw you make. You can cancel a penalty of up to -5 with this feature.
You can use this feature three times. You regain all expended uses after you finish a short or long rest.
Starting at 9th level, you can cancel both a disadvantage and a penalty to one of the listed rolls you make with a single use of this feature.

classFeature.name: Determination improvement
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can cancel both a disadvantage and a penalty to one of the listed rolls you make with a single use of this feature.

classFeature.name: Know Your Enemy
entries: At 3rd level, if you spend at least 10 minutes examinating a creature through observation, interaction, or combat, you can collect certain information about its capabilities or demeanors. Make a DC 10 Insight check. If you succeed on the check, you learn one of the following creature's characteristics of your choice:

items: If one of its ability scores is equal, superior, or inferior to yours.
If its Armor Class and hit point maximum is equal, superior, or inferior to yours.
Your choice of one skill, tool, saving throw, or weapon proficiency it has if its total modifier is equal, superior, or inferior to yours.
Vulnerability, resistance, or immunity to a damage type you choose.
Any demeanor, tic, and vocal inflection it has along with their meaning, if it has one.
What causes it to shift to a friendly, indifferent, or hostile attitude.

entries: You learn an additional characteristic of your choice for every 5 points you get with your check above the DC. You can choose to learn an ability score or proficiency it has multiple times in this way.
Once you use this feature on a creature, you can't use it on it again for the next hour.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat style and techniques, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your archetype grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 15th, and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted by your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted by your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 20th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.
The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 17th level in this class.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack (2)
entries: At 11th level, you can attack three times whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack (3)
entries: At 17th level, you can attack three times whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Combat Expertise
entries: You learn the strengths and weaknesses of your combat style. At 5th level, whenever you make a contested check using Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution, you have advantage on that check.

You also become a freak for the history of anything combat related. Whenever you make an Intelligence (History) check related to combat or adventuring, you are considered proficient in that skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

classFeature.name: Relentless
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you roll initiative and have no superiority dice remaining, you regain 1 superiority die. You also regain a superiority die when you or an ally score a critical hit or you succeed on a saving throw.

classFeature.name: Knowledge Advantage
entries: They say knowing is half the battle, but only a few can use their knowledge to their advantage. At 19th level, when you use your {@classFeature Know Your Enemy|Fighter Rework|DZC:ANA|3|DZC:ANA}, you can designate the target as your Main Target for the next 8 hours. For the duration, you have advantage on ability checks to recall information about them, and your target can't make an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw with advantage against you.
A creature is no longer your Main Target if you see its corpse or if you designate a different creature as your Main Target.

classFeature.name: Legendary Warrior
entries: You have reached the peak of your career, becoming an adventurer like no other ever seen. At 20th level, whenever you spend a Superiority Dice, you gain a +5 bonus to the roll you used it for and 5 temporary hit points.
In addition, when you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the maneuvers you know and replace it with a different one.

optionalfeature.name: Changing Weapons
entries: You learn the Swift Hands technique.

optionalfeature.name: Bludgeoning Weapons
entries: You learn the Crushing Blow technique.

optionalfeature.name: Piercing Weapons
entries: You learn the Poker technique.

optionalfeature.name: Slashing Weapons
entries: You learn the Bleeding technique.

optionalfeature.name: Shield
entries: You can equip a shield the moment you roll initiative (no action required) at the cost of a -3 penalty to your initiative roll.

optionalfeature.name: Light Armor
entries: If you were to be hit by a critical attack, or were to take damage that would reduce you to 0 hit points, you can choose to destroy the light armor you're wearing, reducing that instance of damage to 0.

optionalfeature.name: Medium Armor
entries: You increase by 1 the maximum Dexterity modifier you can add to your AC while wearing medium armor.

optionalfeature.name: Heavy Armor
entries: While wearing heavy armor, the bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage that you take is reduced by 3.

optionalfeature.name: Durability
entries: At the start of your turn, if you have less than your maximum hit points, you can take a deep breath to regain your strength. When you do so, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 1d10 + your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1).
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: At the start of your turn, if you have less than your maximum hit points

optionalfeature.name: Perseverance
entries: With enough time, you can carve a path through the mightiest mountain. Standing up from {@condition prone} only costs you 10 feet of movement.

optionalfeature.name: Stamina
entries: You can momentarily ignore the fatigue of your body. When you roll initiative, if you have the {@condition exhaustion} condition, you can choose to reduce its level by one for the duration of the combat, or until you are knocked unconscious.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Unyielding
entries: If you start your turn at 0 hit points, you can choose to regain 1 hit point at the cost of one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

optionalfeature.name: Ambush
entries: When you make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check or an initiative roll, you can expend one superiority die and add the die to the roll, provided you aren't {@condition incapacitated}.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Dexterity (Stealth) check or an initiative roll

optionalfeature.name: Bait and Switch
entries: When you're within 5 feet of a creature on your turn, you can expend one superiority die and switch places with that creature, provided you spend at least 5 feet of movement and the creature is willing and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.
Roll the superiority die. Until the start of your next turn, you or the other creature (your choice) gains a bonus to AC equal to the number rolled.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you're within 5 feet of a creature on your turn

optionalfeature.name: Brace
entries: When a creature you can see moves into the reach you have with the melee weapon you're wielding, you can use your reaction to expend one superiority die and make one attack against the creature, using that weapon. If the attack hits, add the superiority die to the weapon's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature you can see moves into your reach

optionalfeature.name: Commanding Presence
entries: When you make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}), a Charisma ({@skill Performance}), or a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, you can expend one superiority die and add the superiority die to the ability check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Charisma (Intimidation), a Charisma (Performance), or a Charisma (Persuasion) check

optionalfeature.name: Commander's Strike
entries: When you take the Attack action on your turn, you can forgo one of your attacks and use a bonus action to direct one of your companions to strike. When you do so, choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you and expend one superiority die. That creature can immediately use its reaction to make one weapon attack, adding the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you take the Attack action on your turn and forgo one attack

optionalfeature.name: Disarming Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to disarm the target, forcing it to drop one item of your choice that it's holding. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it drops the object you choose. The object lands at its feet.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Distracting Strike
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to distract the creature, giving your allies an opening. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll. The next attack roll against the target by an attacker other than you has advantage if the attack is made before the start of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Evasive Footwork
entries: When you move, you can expend one superiority die, rolling the die and adding the number rolled to your AC until you stop moving.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you move

optionalfeature.name: Feinting Attack
entries: You can expend one superiority die and use a bonus action on your turn to feint, choosing one creature within 5 feet of you as your target. You have advantage on your next attack roll against that creature this turn. If that attack hits, add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

optionalfeature.name: Goading Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to goad the target into attacking you. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target has disadvantage on all attack rolls against targets other than you until the end of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Grappling Attack
entries: Immediately after you hit a creature with a melee attack on your turn, you can expend one superiority die and then try to grapple the target as a bonus action. Add the superiority die to your Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: Immediately after you hit a creature with a melee attack on your turn

optionalfeature.name: Lunging Attack
entries: When you make a melee weapon attack on your turn, you can expend one superiority die to increase your reach for that attack by 5 feet. If you hit, you add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Maneuvering Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to maneuver one of your comrades into a more advantageous position. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and you choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you. That creature can use its reaction to move up to half its speed without provoking opportunity attacks from the target of your attack.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Menacing Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to frighten the target. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Indomitable
entries: When you fail a saving throw, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to add it to the roll, potentially causing the save to succeed.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you fail a saving throw

optionalfeature.name: Parry
entries: When another creature damages you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to reduce the damage by the number you roll on your superiority die + your Dexterity modifier.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When another creature damages you with a melee attack

optionalfeature.name: Precision Attack
entries: When you make a weapon attack roll against a creature, you can expend one superiority die to add it to the roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a weapon attack roll against a creature

optionalfeature.name: Pushing Attack
entries: When you hit with a weapon attack a creature no more than one size larger than you, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to drive the target back. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and if the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you push the target up to 10 feet away from you.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Quick Toss
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend one superiority die and make a ranged attack with a weapon that has the thrown property. You can draw the weapon as part of making this attack. If you hit, add the superiority die to the weapon's damage roll.

optionalfeature.name: Rally
entries: On your turn, you can use a bonus action and expend one superiority die to bolster the resolve of one of your companions. When you do so, choose a friendly creature who can see or hear you. That creature gains temporary hit points equal to the superiority die roll + your Charisma modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Riposte
entries: When a creature misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction and expend one superiority die to make a melee weapon attack against the creature. If you hit, you add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature misses you with a melee attack

optionalfeature.name: Slowing Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to reduce that creature's speed. Roll your superiority die. The creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or have its speed reduced an ammount in feet equal to 5 times the number rolled on your superiority die. This effect lasts until the start of your next turn. If the maneuver reduces a creature's speed to 0, it becomes {@condition restrained} for the duration.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Sweeping Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to damage another creature with the same attack. Choose another creature within 5 feet of the original target and within your reach. If the original attack roll would hit the second creature, it takes damage equal to the number you roll on your superiority die. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack

optionalfeature.name: Tactical Assessment
entries: When you make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}), an Intelligence ({@skill History}), or a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, you can expend one superiority die and add the superiority die to the ability check.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make an Intelligence (Investigation), an Intelligence (History), or a Wisdom (Insight) check

optionalfeature.name: Trip Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend one superiority die to attempt to knock the target down. You add the superiority die to the attack's damage roll, and if the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target {@condition prone}.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack

subclassFeature.name: Champion
entries: A champion is the first thing that comes to mind when anyone thinks of a fighter, a hero who has defeated great foes by overwhelming them with their physical superiority. These fighters lack any special ability, so they train nonstop to bring their bodies to reach limits beyond what is humanly possible.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your weapon attacks also score a critical hit on a roll of 19. They also score a critical hit on a roll of 18 at 7th level, 17 at 15th, and 16 at 18th.

subclassFeature.name: Physical Expertise
entries: Also at 3rd level, your dedicated physical training bears fruit. You gain proficiency in Acrobatics and Athletics if you don't already have them. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses these skills.
In addition, your jumping distance increases by a number of feet equal to five times your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Remarkable Athlete
entries: At 7th level, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) to any Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution check you make that doesn't already use your proficiency bonus.
In addition, climbing and swimming doesn't cost you extra movement.

subclassFeature.name: Diamond Body
entries: At 15th level, your body can whitstand terrible attacks. When a creature scores a critical hit against you, you can use your reaction to turn it into a normal hit.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When a creature scores a critical hit against you

subclassFeature.name: Survivor
entries: At 18th level, you attain the pinnacle of resilience in battle. At the start of each of your turns, you regain hit points equal to 5 + your Constitution modifier if you have no more than half of your hit points left. You don't gain this benefit if you have 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Shadows
entries: Monks of the Way of the Shadows follow a tradition that values stealth and subterfuge. These monks might be called ninjas or shadowdancers, and they serve as spies and assassins.

Sometimes the members of a ninja monastery are family members, forming a clan sworn to secrecy about their arts and missions. Other monasteries are more like thieves' guilds, hiring out their services to nobles, rich merchants, or anyone else who can pay their fees.

Regardless of their methods, the heads of these monasteries expect from their students unquestioning obedience, to show no scruple on their actions, and to carry their missions without failure. Otherwise, they won't hesitate to deliver severe punishment.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Arts
entries: With your training you are capable of replicating certain spells. At 3rd level, you gain the {@spell message} and {@spell minor illusion} cantrips if you don't already know them. In addition, you can spend 1 ki point to cast {@spell fog cloud}, {@spell silent image}, or {@spell jump}, and you can spend 2 ki points to cast {@spell darkness}, {@spell darkvision}, {@spell pass without trace}, or {@spell silence}.
When you cast {@spell silent image} in this way, you can only use it to create an image of yourself, and you can only cast {@spell jump} on yourself in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Step
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to step from one shadow into another. When you are in dim light or darkness, as a bonus action you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. You then have advantage on the first attack you make on that turn.

subclassFeature.name: Cloak of Shadows
entries: At 11th level, you learn how to become one with the shadows. You can spend 2 ki points when you use your Shadow Step to become {@condition invisible}. You remain {@condition invisible} until you make an attack, cast a spell, or until you get into an area of bright light.

subclassFeature.name: Opportunist
entries: At 17th level, you can exploit a creature's momentary distraction when it is hit by an attack. Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you is hit by an attack made by a creature other than you, you can use your reaction to make an attack against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Elements
entries: This tradition teaches you to harness the energy of the four elements in ways that improve your combat prowess. Bend the forces of nature to invoke harmful effects on your enemies, or to surpass the mortal limits of your body. Some members of this tradition dedicate themselves to a single element, others explore different paths with them, and a few can weave the four elements together.

Each element is often associated with an aspect of an individual's personality or ideology. Air is associated with playfulness, peace, and solving problems from different angles. Earth with toughness, stability, and stubborness. Fire with anger, passion, and direct confrontation. Water with sadness, kindness, and adaptability.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Arts
entries: Each element is contained within a field of study, known as {@filter Elemental Arts|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA}. Each elemental art has its own set of abilities, reflected as options within the features of this subclass. Whenever you gain a feature from this subclass you learn one of its options, each associated to an elemental art ({@filter air|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA:A}, {@filter earth|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA:E}, {@filter fire|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA:F}, and {@filter water|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA:W}).

Another property of these arts is that each has associated damage types, as shown in the Elemental Arts Damage table. Whenever a feature in this subclass refers to the damage of your elemental art, it refers to the ones in the table.

entries.caption: Elemental Arts Damage
colLabels: Maximum Ki Points for a Spell

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Strike
entries: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you learn to release elemental energy from your attacks. Once on your turn, when you hit a target with a weapon attack, you can spend 1 ki point to use an {@filter Elemental Strike|optionalfeature|feature type=DZC:EA:ES} option you know, dealing extra damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die, choosing from one of the damage types of its associated art. Each option has additional effect you can apply with it.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Manifestation
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn to shape the elements' energy into different effects. Once on your turn, you can spend 1 ki point to replace an attack from the Attack action with an {@filter Elemental Manifestation|optionalfeature|feature type=DZC:EA:EM} option you know.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Stances
entries: At 6th level, you learn to infuse yourself with elemental energy. As a bonus action, you can spend 2 ki points to enter a {@filter Primal Stance|optionalfeature|feature type=DZC:EA:PS} option you know for 1 minute. For the duration, you gain the benefits of the chosen option. Your Primal Stance ends early if you are knocked unconscious, if you end it as a bonus action, or until you use this feature again.
Alternatively, you can learn an additional option from one of your previous features.

subclassFeature.name: Step Shift
entries: At 11th level, you learn how to move as one with the elements. Choose one of the {@filter Step Shift|optionalfeature|feature type=DZC:EA:SS}
Alternatively, you can learn an additional option from one of your previous features.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Mastery
entries: At 17th level, you have perfected the primal arts, learning to shape them in special ways. You gain the following benefits:

items: Once on your turn, when you hit a target with a weapon attack, you can deal extra damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die, choosing from one of the damage types of an elemental art you know.
You gain resistance to one of the damage types of an elemental art you know. If you have four arts in a single element, you ignore resistance to that damage.

entries: You also gain one of the following {@filter Elemental Mastery|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:EA:EMa} options of your choice. You must know the amount of elemental arts shown in parenthesis in order to take it.

entries.name: Lightning Adept (Two or more Air Arts)
Acid Adept (Two or more Earth Arts)
Light Adept (Two or more Fire Arts)
Heal Adept (Two or more Water Arts)
Nature's Vessel (One Art in each Elemental)
Monk
entries: Jumping across the roofs with unmatched speed, she pursues the assassin across the city, slowing it little by little with arrows. The criminal now face to face with the wood elf shortly finds themselves immovilized on the ground, unwilling to continue fighting.

The half-orc battles the adult dragon, protecting the sanctuary's gate with nothing but his body. The little warrior holds his adversary by the neck and subdues it to the ground, finishing the assault.

The human unwraps his bandages as the elite knights surround him and ready their weapons. Driven by the thirst of a fight, he dispateches them with hardened strikes that pierce their armors. After taking a deep breath he resumes his hunt for the tyrant.

Whatever their discipline, monks are united in their ability to magically harness the energy that flows in their bodies. Whether channeled as a striking display of combat prowess or a subtler focus of defensive ability and speed, this energy infuses all that a monk does.

entries.name: The Magic of Ki
entries: Monks make careful study of a magical energy that most Martial Archetypes call ki. This energy is an element of the magic that suffuses the multiverse-specifically, the element that flows through living bodies. Monks harness this power within themselves to create magical effects, exceed their bodies' physical capabilities, or alter the state of a creature by manipulating their ki. Using this energy, monks channel uncanny speed and strength into their attacks. As they gain experience, their martial training and their mastery of ki gives them more power over their bodies and the bodies of their foes.

entries.name: Training and Asceticism
entries: Small walled cloisters dot the landscapes of the worlds of D&D, tiny refuges from the flow of ordinary life, where time seems to stand still. The monks who live there seek personal perfection through contemplation and rigorous training. Many entered the monastery as children, sent to live there when their parents died, when food couldn't be found to support them, or in return for some kindness that the monks had performed for their families.

A monastery welcomes anyone seeking refuge, and all its inhabitants must abide by its community rules. However, to be considered a monk, it is required that one persistently and rigurously trains body and spirit, for they believe that only when both work in harmony and are pushed past its limitations everyday that one can reach their perfect self. Such is the goal of every monk. It is for that purpose that many Martial Archetypes have been created, for the path is unique for each individual.

Some monks live entirely apart from the surrounding population, secluded from anything that might impede their spiritual progress. Others are sworn to isolation, emerging only to serve their mentor or a divine power, often to fulfill a spiritual task, others to carry out an important mission. In some cases, they embark themselves on a meaningful journey for self discovery.

The majority of monks don't shun their neighbors, making frequent visits to nearby towns or villages and exchanging their service for food and other goods. As versatile warriors, monks often end up protecting their neighbors from monsters or tyrants.

For a monk, becoming an adventurer is a harsh transition. It means leaving a structured, communal lifestyle to become a wanderer. Thus, those who leave their cloisters don't undertake this change lightly. They work diligently, approaching their adventures as personal tests of their physical and spiritual growth. Monks care little for material wealth and are driven by a desire to accomplish a greater mission than slaying monsters and plundering their treasure.

entries.name: Creating a Monk
entries: As you make your monk character, think about your connection to the monastery where you learned your skills and spent your formative years. Were you an orphan or a child left on the monastery's threshold? Did your parents promise you to the monastery in gratitude for a service performed by the monks? Did you enter this secluded life to hide from a crime you committed? Or did you choose the monastic life for yourself? And why did you choose to study your discipline?

Consider why you left. Did the head of your monastery choose you for a particularly important mission beyond the cloister? Perhaps you were cast out because of some violation of the community's rules. Did you dread leaving, or were you happy to go? Is there something you hope to accomplish outside the monastery? Are you eager to return to your home?
As a result of the structured life of a monastic community and the discipline required to harness ki, monks are almost always lawful in alignment.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a monk quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom. Second, choose the {@background hermit} background. Take the Unarmed Style and when you learn ki features, choose {@optfeature Flurry of Blows|DZC:ANA}, {@optfeature Patient Defense|DZC:ANA}, and {@optfeature Step of the Wind|DZC:ANA}.

entries.name: Can I add this Bonus?
entries: Sometimes an ability, feature, or spell allows you to add a bonus to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, such as the bard's Bardic Inspiration, a war cleric's  Channel Divinity: Guided Strike, the *bless* spell, the martial technique boost offensive, and many others. Other abilities allow you to reroll the die for those die rolls, such as the drunken master monk's Drunkard's Luck. There is another type of abilities, much rarer than the others, ones that allow you to add special effects to your actions, reactions, die rolls, etc., such as the monk's Evasion ki feature. These abilities have in common the lack of key words for its trigger, such as hit, succeed, miss, or fail, which is why you can choose to use these after seeing the roll, but before the DM says wether the roll succeeds or fails.
